children.text: The Supreme Court on Friday overturned its landmark
decision, invalidating federal protections for abortion rights. The decision will quickly limit reproductive health care access for tens of millions of people.

The decision, which is part of a barrage of devastating, precedent-setting Supreme Court rulings this term, surely has many Americans wondering how we arrived at such a dark moment. The answer is simple, even if it is rarely discussed in corporate media: It lies in a giant pile of anonymous cash that was deployed to buy Supreme Court seats, help determine justices‚Äô caseload, and shape their decisions.

A secretive, well-financed dark money network has spent years working to build the Supreme Court‚Äôs radical conservative supermajority and bankrolling many of the politicians and organizations involved in the most controversial cases now before the court, including the abortion rights case decided Friday.
The public will almost certainly never know the identities of the ultra-wealthy individuals and interests who paid to stack this court and influence its decisions, but much of the credit should go to
named Leonard Leo and his cadre of conservative activists.

children.productTitle: Join David Sirota & Krystal Ball on Monday
children.productDescription: Krystal Ball is joining us for Lever Live on Monday to discuss the overturning of Roe and what lies ahead. Join to ask your questions or share your thoughts with Krystal and David live. Free and open to all. Just click the link and then Subscribe to register.

children.text: The co-chairman of the Federalist Society, the conservative lawyers group in Washington, Leo is best known for serving as President Donald Trump‚Äôs top judicial adviser. Leo helped select Trump‚Äôs Supreme Court picks while simultaneously leading a dark money network that boosted their confirmations with TV ads and contributions to conservative groups that promoted the judges.

Leo‚Äôs dark money network has also funded Republican state attorneys general and conservative nonprofits that are backing and even directly arguing some of the most contentious cases before the high court right now.

It is with these cases that the Supreme Court has ended federal protections for abortion rights, dismantled the high court precedent requiring police officers to inform people of their rights to remain silent and to an attorney when they‚Äôre being detained,
on carrying concealed firearms, and handed conservative state lawmakers more power to chip away at Americans‚Äô voting rights.
In other upcoming decisions, the court could soon strip environmental regulators of
their ability to regulate carbon emissions
So to fully understand how we got here, it‚Äôs important to follow the money ‚Äî at least to the extent that we can.
Quietly Building The Court‚Äôs Conservative Supermajority
Leo and his allies first formed the Judicial Crisis Network in 2005 to help confirm George W. Bush‚Äôs Justices, John Roberts and Samuel Alito ‚Äî and Leo

a ‚Äúdecisive role‚Äù in both of their selections. The organization has grown quietly and steadily since then, and played a key role in flipping the court and building its 6-3 conservative supermajority.
In 2016, following the death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia, the Judicial Crisis Network spent
on an advertising and advocacy campaign to pave the way for Republican senators to avoid holding a vote on President Barack Obama‚Äôs court pick, Merrick Garland.

The Judicial Crisis Network and its sister group, a charitable organization called the Judicial Education Project, both
big donations to allied conservative nonprofits that helped create an echo chamber supporting the judges‚Äô nominations.
to remake the Judicial Crisis Network and Judicial Education Project and expand their scope.

The Judicial Crisis Network was rebranded as the Concord Fund, while the Judicial Education Project was renamed the 85 Fund. Both organizations maintained their original names as trade names; the Concord Fund continues to
under the alias of the Judicial Crisis Network.

children.text: Now, both organizations have grown into financial juggernauts. The Concord Fund reported raising more than $48 million between July 2020 and June 2021, a period of time that included Barrett‚Äôs confirmation. The 85 Fund
Throughout their history, these organizations have done an exceptional job of keeping their donors secret, while raising giant sums from just a few contributors.
According to its most recent tax return, which was
by the watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, the Concord Fund raised nearly all of its recent $48 million haul from two anonymous donors. As
, one of those donors is the Rule of Law Trust, a nonprofit helmed by Leo, which gave the group $22 million in 2020. None of the
and obviously ludicrously wealthy donors to the Rule of Law Trust have been disclosed.
from the 45Committee, a dark money group
with the billionaire Ricketts family, which owns the Chicago Cubs.
The 85 Fund, meanwhile, received more than $20 million in 2020 from a nonprofit called Donors Trust. The latter organization has long been known as a ‚Äú
,‚Äù because billionaires use it as a pass-through vehicle to disguise their donations to conservative groups.
A Two-Pronged Attack On The Judiciary

Leo‚Äôs dark money network has spearheaded a two-pronged attack on the judiciary: First it has worked to install conservative judges, then it has worked to bring those appointees specific cases designed to destroy previous precedents, along with amicus briefs, or ‚Äúfriend of the court‚Äù filings, offering them rationales for doing so.

In its first mission to populate the bench with right-wing ideologues, Leo and his allies have worked closely with Republican Senate leaders. In its 2020-21 tax return, the Concord Fund reported donating $9 million to One Nation, a dark money group affiliated with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who led the Republican strategy to deny Garland a vote as Obama‚Äôs nominee in 2016.

blocking a vote on Garland‚Äôs nomination by arguing that the seat should not be filled in an election year. But in 2020, McConnell led the campaign to swiftly install Barrett to the court despite Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg‚Äôs death coming just
before the election. Barrett was confirmed

children.productDescription: On this week‚Äôs Lever Time: David Sirota discusses Lindsey Graham‚Äôs comments on cutting Social Security and Medicare; Andrew Perez visits a pop-up medical clinic in Joe Manchin‚Äôs home state; and Julia Rock explores why New York Dems recently killed a renewable energy bill.

children.text: Those maneuvers, supported with advocacy and donations from Leo‚Äôs Concord Fund and 85 Fund, helped turn what could be a 5-4 Democratic majority now into a 6-3 conservative supermajority that just overturned longstanding Supreme Court precedents on abortion rights and policing, and may soon gut the government‚Äôs ability to regulate greenhouse gases and potentially much more.

As conservative judges have been installed throughout the judiciary, the Concord Fund and the 85 Fund have simultaneously financed the Republican attorneys general and nonprofits that are supporting and, in some instances, directly leading the highest-stakes cases before the Supreme Court right now. The Concord Fund has long been the top financier of the Republican Attorneys General Association (RAGA), which works to elect GOP state attorneys general, donating more than $17 million to the organization since 2014, according to

Meanwhile, other groups funded by Leo‚Äôs network have been filing amicus briefs offering legal justification for some of the more destructive cases before the Supreme Court this term.  In their most recent annual tax returns, the 85 Fund reported distributing $34 million in grants to political groups and nonprofits, while the Concord Fund gave out $28 million to nonprofits.

The playbook is now straightforward: Leo‚Äôs dark-money network installs right-wing judges, then Republican attorneys general boosted by Leo‚Äôs network bring cases and amicus briefs, while other groups funded by the same network file their own briefs ‚Äî all to create the appearance of broad-based support for extremist rulings.
Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization
handed down Friday, illustrates how the multi-faceted scheme works in practice.
Mississippi Republican Attorney General Lynn Fitch led the case to overturn
. Fitch, who benefited from $225,000 in donations and spending by the Concord Fund-backed RAGA in her 2018 race, asked the Supreme Court to uphold a Mississippi law that would
ban most abortions at 15 weeks of pregnancy
, even in cases of rape or incest. Eighteen Republican attorneys general filed a
. The Concord Fund has donated $1 million to the Republican Governors Association this election cycle, according to Political MoneyLine.
review of their most recent tax returns, the Concord Fund and the 85 Fund donated to a long list of groups that filed amicus briefs in the Supreme Court abortion case: the
($2.3 million from the Concord Fund); Former Vice President Mike Pence‚Äôs

This scheme has been consistently replicated in other cases before the high court:
‚Äî In a 6-3 decision handed down Tuesday, the court‚Äôs conservatives held that Maine must give public money to private religious schools. The decision
a major infringement on the notion of separation between church and state in the U.S., and threatens the concept of a secular public education.

signed by 21 Republican state attorneys general, who are generally elected with support from the Concord Fund-backed RAGA. Briefs were also filed by

to the Independent Women‚Äôs Forum in 2020, while the Concord Fund donated $500,000 to its sister group, Independent Women‚Äôs Voice, between 2020-21.

‚Äî The Supreme Court handed down a ruling in this major gun case on Thursday knocking down New York‚Äôs concealed carry law. The ruling
could invalidate most gun control laws
Twenty-six Republican attorneys general, many of whom are supported by RAGA, filed an amicus
supporting the New York State Rifle & Pistol Association, which is fighting to weaken the state‚Äôs gun laws. The Leo-backed Independent Women‚Äôs Law Center also filed a

‚Äî On Thursday, Justices ruled that state lawmakers can intervene in a lawsuit filed against North Carolina concerning the constitutionality of the state‚Äôs restrictive voter ID law. Lawmakers sought to intervene in the case because they disagree with the state attorney general‚Äôs handling of the matter.

of the ruling is that in states with a GOP-controlled legislature and a Democratic attorney general, Republican lawmakers will be able to defend voter suppression laws from challenges, even if the state‚Äôs attorney general wanted to settle.

‚Äî The case will determine whether states have the authority to prosecute non-Native Americans who commit crimes against Indigenous people on tribal lands. States currently have jurisdiction when the culprit and victim are both non-Indian. Handing states the authority to prosecute in the cases where offenders are non-Indian would have sweeping consequences for tribal sovereignty, upsetting ‚Äúthe balances struck between Congress, the tribes, and the states for more than a century,‚Äù as
